claim.text: The Earthship buildings of Taos, New Mexico, take this further, routing all greywater through interior 'botanical cells' — greenhouse planters that treat the water before it irrigates exterior food gardens
claim.claim: Earthship buildings in Taos, New Mexico route greywater through interior botanical cells before exterior irrigation

results.summary: Earthship buildings in Taos, NM do use interior botanical cells (greenhouse planters) to filter greywater before it goes to exterior irrigation.
results.detail: Earthships, developed by architect Michael Reynolds in Taos, New Mexico, use a well-documented water treatment system where greywater from sinks and showers flows through interior 'botanical cells' — raised planter beds in the greenhouse portion of the building. Plants in these cells filter and consume nutrients from the greywater. The treated water then goes to a second use, typically toilet flushing or exterior landscape irrigation. This is a core feature of Earthship design documented in Earthship Biotecture materials.

The claim is consistent with agricultural data for the Edmonton region in USDA hardiness zone 4a.
